description.text: I made this so that I can keep my wallet and my keys in the same place. The dimensions are in inches and on the drawing picture. I printed the inner part in ivory and the outer part in red so that the baseball button and the Cardinals appear ivory through the outer red cover.

Here is my design for mounting a direct drive. Tired of the oozing! so for now this will work until I can get some money for the flex-drives. Down sides: added weight & limited to 1 extruder. It worked perfect with PLA.  ABS shrunk a bit so you may need to scale it up.  
Why did I make this?  
If you get a 3D printer you have to make a cover for something right?  That way you can whip out your phone and say "Oh by the way, I made this bitchin' cover for my phone on my 3D printer."  You will be an instant hit at the party....if it is attended by the cast of "Big Bang Theory."  
Let me know what modifications you recommend!  
Thanks,  
Ben

title: Tie Fighter & X-Wing Laser Cut Ornaments - C4 Labs

description.text:
My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ Hello everybody! Here's something different to spice up the holidays! I work with a company called C4 Labs. http://c4labs.net We make all sorts of things, usually with a laser cutter, like Raspberry Pi and Arduino enclosures and sell them online. This year we participated in some holiday shows and made some geeky stuff for people to enjoy! While we ramp up for the next year and expand our capabilities, we thought it would be great to give back to the community and what better way than with some ornaments! Anyone with access to a laser cutter can slice up these bad boys and stage a holiday space battle of epic proportions! If you like these and are interested in some of our other goodies, please check us out at the links below! Website: http://goo.gl/gd2uVm

After someone mentioned the idea of a head tracker mount i redid the snapon mount to accomedate two servos (pan,tilt)
This is modeled from a generic 9g servo found on thingy so the fit might be alitle off depending on your servo off choice. Still searching trough my servo list to find one that fits like a glove, if you find the one please lett me know. The other side of the servo is ment to have two 7,5mm bearings fitted with a shaft off choice glued in the middle. Still havent found any bearing that would work so might have to widen the holes to fit yours.
Other than that you just have to drill out your own spline size in the camera holder. Camera holder has room for 11mm thrust bearing.
for removing the cap to the air spring on rock shox pike and similar forks. actual socket size 24mm. recommend printing with 4 shells.

author: Pezzi33

description.text: So you go into the hardware store and you look around at all the cool things that used to cost so much before you had a 3D printer. This is one of the most useful items I found that we can make. In the store they can cost between $.75-$4 for a nylon version, depending on the size of the nut. I took it upon myself to CAD up some to make ABS nuts. These are real handy when you are creating a Mendel and don't want to hurt yourself on the bolt heads. They are in the US standard sizes, since this is the cheapest materials I have available to me right now. I encourage others to make metric versions.

• Print object.
  • Smother in acetone to seal the surfaces.
  • Retap threads so they go on smoothly.

author: Pezzi33

title: Hood rod holder grommet for Corolla 2014

description.text: Rubber Grommet printed with NinjaFlex, to substitute the original hard plastic part which created noise under certain conditions.

If printing with NinjaFlex on an UP Mini this are the settings I used (printing NinjaFlex on an Up mini was a lot trickier than I thought).
  • Extruder Temp: 259?
  • Quality: Fine
  • Resolution: 0.20mm
  • Fill: Loose
  • Raft: No raft
    • In an UP mini not using those setting produces, well... junk!

After I had an accident and the whole front was replaced, I kept hearing a strange sound only at about 11000RPM's, they where not able to fine any mechanical issues at the body shop nor at the dealer, everything seemed to be in place, and the noise was tricky to reproduce to say the least but quite annoying. After some trial an error I noticed that it had something to do with the Hood rod, since removing it took care of the sound, the original grommet is made of hard plastic (I suspect some sort of Nylon) and it seems like once removed it breaks and needs to be replaced, maybe they kept the original after replacing the front, any how it seemed hard enough not to grab the rod strongly though creating noise when it vibrated.   
I looked for a rubber one with not much success and since I had a printer and some NinjaFlex why not make my own? :)

A Lamp/Wall Sconce

Lamp Instructions
  • Glue Lamp Bottom part 1 and 2 together.
  • Glue Corner Spikes to bottom and top.
  • Glue Center Spike to Lamp top.
  • Glue Side Posts to corners of Lamp Top with notches for the windows facing in.
  • Glue Windows(clear printer filament) to side posts.
  • Insert light bulb socket($3.00) to center of Lamp Bottom and run wires through tube.
  • Place mounting bracket to wall and wire light bulb socket into house wire.
  • Apply glue to mounting arm and insert into mounting bracket.
  • Insert light bulb, then insert Lamp top into Lamp bottom.

author: jac23

title: Lulzbot TAZ Fan Dual Duct with Tap ready holes

description.text:
The only difference here is the holes for the fan are smaller.  They are sized for a Tap (3mm x 0.50) that will allow the stock screws to be reused.  Not as strong as press insert nuts but strong enough to hold the fan.
If you have a Taz5 or the new Hexagon Metal hot end for your Taz4, then this modified fan duct is not needed as it has a separate fan that cools the hot end directly.

comments.text: Had the same issues with needing the smaller holes as well.
comments.author: striegel

comments.text: When I designed this and built the first couple of them, the hole size was exactly right to re-use the screws that come with the fan. Some people have reported that the hole size is too big, others report that they are just right as-is. I suspect it mostly comes down to your slicer settings.

author: hsroberts

title: Rivet Pivot Test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since a Thing-a-Week was too often, it's time to try a thing-a-day!
TAD Day 2 - http://thing-a-day.com/rivet-pivot-test
TAD Day 3 - http://thing-a-day.com/rivet-pivot-test-2
http://thing-a-day.com/tag/IHeartRobotics Previous Adventures
http://www.iheartrobotics.com/search/label/thing-a-month
http://www.iheartrobotics.com/search/label/thing-a-week

It would be useful for building robots to be able to cheaply and easily create a rotating connection between two 3D printed parts. This is an initial test using rivets. None of these tests produced a joint that rotated freely, but this might be useful for connection where friction is desirable such as pose-able stop motion figure.

comments.text: They use rivets like this for linkages in a lot of things, usually with sheet metal straps of the same design as these. I think the trick is to oversize the hole so that the side expansion doesn't cause it to bind. Perhaps more importantly you need some kind of clearance between the two faces of the work, using an overly long rivet will make a sloppy joint, you want a way to get a small, repeatable and parallel amount of clearance. I know I've read somewhere to use a piece of paper like a washer between the two link arms and then tear it out afterwards, you may have to soak it in water and wiggle the joint a bit to get it to come out dependent on how tight the joint ends up.
comments.author: jstkatz

comments.text: Try a different kind of rivet ;) Blind rivets expand - this is how they get their joint strength...
comments.author: trebuchet03

comments.text: I'm going to try that next. They are probably cheaper than bushings.
comments.author: trebuchet03

comments.text: Perhaps a slightly more complicated, but workable solution; Put one of those little silver cylinders used in beading into the hole.  Then put in the rivet.  The silver cylinder will act as the force to maintain enough integrity within the plastic.  The rivet won't bulge out other than outside the plastic, giving you a sliding hinge?
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Something like a bushing may work, I'll probably test that when I test a shackle design.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yes, exactly, a bushing.  And it looks like a washer would fit in your design nicely.

This is a drop-in replacement for the Subaru BRZ/Scion FRS cupholder with an enlarged phone pocket sized to fit a Nexus 6. It also includes a cutout for a single coil Qi charger. Note that the phone pocket is DEEP it nearly swallows my Nexus 6, which is a huge "phone." I had to do this to get the charge coil to line up with the receiver coil in my phone.

Just print, glue your qi coil in, and attach the top via the screw hole in the middle, or you could just glue it all together. I wanted to be able to take it apart in case the coil went bad or something.  
To print the top, you'll need support structure because of the lip. I also used a raft because of the small surface area actually touching the bed.  
There is a hole in the bottom of each cup, these are to run a couple of small wires for some edge lit acrylic or something. I haven't decided.  
I also attached to source files (.ipt). These are Autodesk Inventor 2015 files. Be forewarned, though, I'm not very good at workflow, so expect the part to break if you try to modify it too much.

comments.text: OMG thank you. I have been planning on creating my own custom drink holder, phone dock, insert for my BRZ since I got it. This is going to save me a bunch of time. My plan is to create a section that extends over the front and includes an actual Qi cradle for my phone instead of that slot. Now I dont have to spend hours taking measurements.

author: jrcarter

title: Landing Skid for Super-X 125mm Micro Brushless Quadcopter

description.text:
Stock skid tends to break easily, this replacement is designed to be put under the zip ties holding the ESCs. The last photo shows an alternative way of assembly where the ESCs reside on a double sided adhesive pad and the leg is zip tied closer to the motor. You can also put a heat shrink on it for dampening. These ESCs are fragile, so zip tie with a leg can produce additional stress, consider using this way. While it may look fragile, it's very tough and should survive most of the crashes. 4 pieces weigh under 2g (print with zero infill and thin perimeter, for Cura I set shell thickness = 0.4 = nozzle size). Super-X 125mm Micro Brushless Quadcopter
RCGroups Forum thread

Zero infill
Top/bottom thickness: 0.50

Shell thickness: 0.4 (perimeter: 1) Print it flat (STL is already rotated).

description.text: Just having some fun experimenting with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53453 trying to make it print without any support, fit the key and allowing different sizes. It will likely work better in smaller size, you can use slicer to resize it further. This is based on fastkite's excellent customizable cuffs & collar, however the original had a distinct disadvantage for me in that it needs support material to build. To attempt to fix that, I'm building the hinge closed, so it's self-supporting. NOTE this requires a priinter with good tolerances and calibration so the hinges don't stick to each other. To aid with this, the expected tolerance has been exposed to the customizer as Hinge_Play. Another nod for printing without support is the addition of slight slope on the underside of the "attachment loops" optional on both sides of the bracelet. This slope is only on the underside, not on the top side since support isn't needed there. Additionally, the hinge holes on the open side have been increased so the printed pins have a chance of fitting inside (although the pins still print vertical, which is challenging, I recommend printing without pins and using a toothpick or whatever fits to save time). I also modified it to print with lower thickness/width ratio because I like my bracelets long and not overly thick. The halves have been made almost symmetrical, because I like things symmetric, so technically if you print two you can mix & match between the two (Remembering that they print with one hinge already formed, so would need to drill through that). In addition I played around with the hole decoration, because a long closed bracelet could become rather sweaty. The default printing size is small because I didn't want to waste plastic experimenting; increase at your own peril.

author: dannywilliamo

title: 303 British Laser Bore Sighter to 12 gauge adaptor

description.text:
Adaptor to allow a bore alignment laser for a 0.303 British calibre to be used in a standard 12 gauge chamber. Why buy 2 bore lasers when you can use the same one for 2 firearms...   
Being able to sight in or test technique without using real ammunition is a big plus.  
NOTE: Do not use with live ammo... That would be unwise and potentially fatal.

Using standard sizes for both 303British and 12 gauge catridges, the adaptor was created. outer radius was reduced by 0.25mm to allow clearance in shotgun, and inner radius were increased by 0.5mm to allow for easy fitting of 303 cartridge.  
Printed on Up! mini, no filing or size changes were required.  base was smoothed to remove some support material.  
Embossed writing around adaptor was filled with liquid paper and scraped flat when dry, to increase readability of WARNINGS

title: Hobby Knife For X-acto No.11 Blades

description.text: This hobby knife uses X-acto brand No.11 blades (the most common and popular blade size). The knife handle has been modified from a round shape to an octagonal shape like a pencil which makes it easier to hold and also helps prevent the knife from rolling off a table or desk, which always results in the tip of the blade being damaged. Also included is a safety cap/cover.

Print out each part vertically as shown and assemble. When installing the blade, make sure you have it as far down as
it will go in the holder. This will keep the blade from moving around. Do not overtighten the knurled sleeve. The safety cap/cover might be a little tight at first, just keep
forcing it over the knurled sleeve until it loosens up.

description.text: Saboneteira comum

All submissions to this challenge must combine at least two other designs from Thingiverse Rules:
  • Needs to be printable (at least partlyâ€¦ Unicorns and Frostruders included) on a Makerbot
  • Needs to combine at least two other designs (can include new designs of your own making, but they need to be posted as separate items)
  • Post submissions on Thingiverse by 8pm CST on Feb 27, 2011.
  • Multiple entries are allowed, but they must be distinct from one another.
  • To enter be sure and tag your Thing with the word â€œMashMeUpâ€
    • The entries will be judged using the following criteria: * Number of Likes on Thingiverse * Number of times it has been made by someone else * Average Thingiverse rating * Printability (not just fitting it in the space but also how many separate prints are required) * Effort put into design (based on testing and revisions (if at all needed), how well does it fit the challenge) * Mechanical design (based on # of pieces, possible modes for failure, etc) * Does it build on previous challenge winners? * Future for use in other Thingiverse designs * Are multiple (editable) file formats provided? * Number of other items combined from Thingiverse to make new design CONGRATS TO EMMITT, the winner of $100 Makerbot store credit (from Makerbot) and $56 cash prize ($50 from me, $6 from people through Flattr). Here is the link to his winning entry (Heart Gears):
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6291 You should all print one.... this thing is pretty sweet (all puns intended). I think the only improvement could be changing the gears to all prime numbers so getting it back to a perfect fit will drive people insaaaaaneeeeee. New challenge later this week - Keep your eyes peeled.

Back to posting on Thingiverse! Never said the prize pool......
$50 cash and $100 Makerbot store credit goes to the winner Any flattr money will also be added to the prize pool

Segment A - 3 required - Horizontal segments
Segment B - 4 required - Vertical segments

Looking for PLA? We offer unmatched 1.75 PLA print quality with our SP Series PLA. While working on the Rostock BI edition we also tested different types of PLA filament spools. We found that when using spools with different inner diameters a versatile system is a must. We designed our spool holder to allow for a quick switch between many spool types. Our main design objectives were stability, reliability and versatility. Follow us on twitter for updates @BootsIndustries The spool holder is comprised of three main parts: 1) The spool holder base 2) The rotating platform 3) The spool adaptor The key to our design is that you can modify and print several spool adaptors that match the types of spools you have on hand. Everything is held in place by gravity with the rotating platform connecting to the spool adaptor.

Sketchup model and .stl files are included. You can modify the spool adaptor in the sketchup model to suit your individual needs. We have included the .stl files for 3 dimensions of spools we have encountered so far. Assemble the spool holder as per the exploded view (view full size), the M4 nut will thread into the plastic and stay in place. We recommend printing your spool holder in PLA or ABS with an infill > 30%. Depending on your printerÃ¢â¬â¢s performance, printing infill before perimeters may yield better results for the rotating platform and spool adaptor. The picture shows a part printed in PLA 1.75 mm BOM: 1 X M4 20 mm Cap Screw
1 X M4 Washer
1 X 608 [8 x 22 x 7] Ball Bearing

author: bones2go

title: Fan and climate control knobs and levers for 1985 Vanagon (T3)

description.text:
Initial iteration:
Fan and climate control knobs and levers for 1985 Vanagon
VW P/N: 251-259-371D : Plastic Control Lever (4 per car)
VW P/N: 251-959-513: Plastic Control Knob to select fan speed in front and rear of vehicle. (2 per car) These parts are tested. They are a bit snug and required using a fair bit of force to install. However, once installed they feel quite good and sturdy. I don't think the 'sliding' action, parallel to the length of the vehicle, is working correctly. They are too stiff and I think a bit more clearance is needed around where these attach to the metal lever inside the control unit. Truly the only consequence is that the levers stick out kind of far when in the middle setting.

Used Inventor to draw, and a Stratasys machine to print. I'm a fan of open-source, but my place of work has this sweet-assed machine, so I thought I'd use it. One can use a simpler machine with some mods/reorientation/and some thought to the file. 178 micron layer resolution
100% fill
ABS

description.text: A clean and simple amplifier for your mobile phone. Certainly not a new idea but I needed something to help cleanup my desk and allow me to play music (or just hear the phone ringing from the opposite end of the house!). And of course I needed it to be my own unique design. Check out the video of this working at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=roSVK2uKq50 A modified version of this won the i.Materialise 3D Printed Wood Challenge (http://i.materialise.com/blog/entry/announcing-five-winners-of-our-3d-printed-wood-challenge) Check the dimensions of your phone against the slot dimensions pictured - I designed this for smaller phones like my old Samsung Galaxy S2, so you may want to scale up the design prior to printing if you're using a giant phone. Read more about the design of this product on my blog, including the multi-coloured effect created by swapping filament colours during printing. https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/category/phone-sound-amplifier/ Enjoy!

title: Maker Man - Running
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Running Maker(bot) Man. Originally created to print quickly and calibrate a machine. Was also good for figuring out that the x or y axis are flipped and nailing down skeinforge settings while not completely wasting plastic filament. (I gave most of my extra away as samples and cast a few up to test 3d prints in bronze casting).
I was pleasantly surprised that some of the worst skeinforge settings and prints turned out to look the best cast in bronze.
These where made a really long time ago and never got around to uploading them. Figured I should share.
Print, check orientation to see if you x or y axis are flipped. scale height from 2mm to 1mm for really quick printing. Drill a whole in his head to use as a key fob for your gym membership.

I think I bumped into the same problems as a couple of the others when printing so I fixed those issues for me. I redid the zip tag, added the zip teeth, thickened his neck a little, and made his eyes and mouth more prominent.

Printed on My Ultimaker 2, add the zip tag in front of his legs so that additional support is not added here, I used these settings:
  • 0.2mm layer thickness
  • 20mm/sec
  • 40% infill
  • Support touching buildplate
    • A bit extreme I know but I love the low poly head and it came out great. Took 3 hours to print. Once printed the zip tag slides on sideways. I did think of slicing him in half and printing, but there is no need. A little bit of scalpel clean-up on the fingers and between his legs and he's good to go.

This is a childsafe candle, made it for my 4 year old son. The light comes from a led bike light which are cheap and readily available in my country (the netherlands). The parts were printed on my Zortrax and only the candle needs a bit of support in the middle, which (on the Zortrax) an then easily be removed. The .rsdoc file is the design file if you need to tweak it. It was designed using my favorite design program: Design Spark, which can be used for free.
Disclaimer: I have no commercial connections to DS at all, just love the way that designs can be rounded after they are drawn. Many thingiverse designs would benefit a bit more rounded corners.

title: Rubber band gun - no screws required

description.text:
Glue is also optional, but your milage may vary with the tolerances of your printer.  
I loved the simplicity of the original rubber band gun by @gavilan, but the need for screws, bolts washers, and no idea what size elastic band to use was a bit of a downer. So I built this with the innards.  
I also made the barrel shorter to work with size 10 rubber bands, well a standard is as good as a rest. The trigger elastic band is a size 16.  
Bring on the zombie apocalypse!!

author: quinto67

title: Arch of Titus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The product I decided to design is the Triumphal Arc of Titus, which is a monument constructed by Roman Emperor Titus during the ancient times. The product itself was very interesting to make and overall not too complex to design. If you look at the actual monument you can tell the design is basically a large rectangle with the center of it cut out to be arc shaped and then cut straight down from each side of the arc. Each grove and bump on the arc is based on what the actual monument contains and I had tried to make it the most historically correct appearing replica. My motivation to this was when looking on the site for any replicaâ€™s of buildings, statues, or wonders the choices were limited to a bare minimum. So I decided to design a monument based off of Roman architecture, basically a replica of the original. I personally am interested in Roman history and thought this would be a fun project to undergo. Although I couldnâ€™t have an exact model it still came out to be fairly similar.
The process in designing this was really basic. First having already downloaded the Autodesk Inventor program you must find your constraints to the Makerbot, which in my case was to be 4x4 inches maximum. Then I designed the actual piece in the inventor program. My first step was to make a rectangle only 2x3 inches so it would print out well and the details would show more clearly. Then I had extruded my piece to one inch. Looking at it you have a rectangle, but this is when the arc comes into play. I then sketched an arc about 3/4th of an inch down the center of the rectangle and had it have a diameter of about 1.5 inches. After that I extruded the arc and everything under it within the 1.5 inch diameter. I followed up by adding extrusions outwards from the design, giving it bumps along the service to give it the authentic look. After completing the design I uploaded it to the Makerbot and waited almost 1 hour and 30 minutes for it print.
The overall product came out nicely, although some faults involving the cooling process affected the overall shape of the design. After printing out most of the design, by the time it was half way over the cool down process had the plastic contract upwards basically warping it. If you have a heated platform to keep a consecutive heat flow to the product then you shouldnâ€™t have a problem with the shape. The overall more important part of it looks good, but I was going to have the design printed twice so I could glue them together to actually have the triumphal arc completed, not just half of it.
If anyone enjoys this at all or finds ways of improving it please feel free to try it yourself or give me constructive criticism. One thing that would be cool that I thought of doing, but couldnâ€™t manage to do so was to have the design of the actual Latin inscription printed out on the design. Well hopefully you can make something similar or other cool building replicas! Good Luck!

comments.text: With what fill did you print it? Maybe reduce the inFill percentage to prevent warping.

description.text: Deadbolt Key Handle is a push-on knob that slips over most standard house keys with a 22mm x 24mm head like those made by Kwikset. Provides easy access in the dark or during emergencies & still removable when you leave the house.

Deadbolt Key Handle was printed in 3mm ABS (use gold filament to more closely match brass, or glow-in-the-dark filament to see in the dark). Disable Generate Support Material under Print Settings to avoid filling the key slot. Typical print time is under 20mins using 25% infill.

comments.text: I was thinking on doing something similar, I used to have Mul-T-lock deadbolts with what they called "Captive Key" that is basically a key but with a thumb turn, now I don't have those deadbolts anymore since I moved, I have a regular double sided deadbolt but is annoying having to use the key every time I'm inside the house in order to open the door, Luckily I bumped into your post, I want to try to make one with the same shape since its really nice (just need to get me a mouse first since I lost my usb receiver :/ )

description.text: This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! This force was co-created by fellow Ill Gotten Gamer, Nate Stephens

Here are the basic pieces you need to build a curved LEGO creation. I've included the basic 2x2, 3x2 and 4x2 bricks in a range of radii (6, 7, 8 and 9 studs). Also I've found it handy to have a gauge plate that can be used to sort the different radius pieces as they can easily get mixed up. The gauge plate can also be used as a base plate for building your creations. All of these bricks (and more) can be created using the customizable version found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:578754 I've found it very liberating to build with these curved shapes. It is also a big challenge integrating them with standard, rectangular LEGO bricks. Enjoy!

Designed in OpenSCAD, sliced in Simplify3D, printed on a MakerBot Replicator2 with Elmer's Craft Bond glue stick on a glass build plate with PushPlastic filament and the following settings: Infill = 20%
Layer height = 0.2
No. shells = 4
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220C No support is needed.

description.text: would appreciate it if you print this please let me know ,

Here is my take on upright stand for MBP (13" or 15"). It is for later models - 18mm thickness. Design allowed for 1.5mm felt on both sides.   
It is size that just fits Robox 3D printer.  
Note: Complete version is updated as v2. Original was 250mm (by mistake) while v2 is now 200mm - exactly what is easily printable by Robox.

There are to options - print complete stand, upright, with support (I haven't done that, yet) or two arcs, two connectors and two distancers. Use one of arcs to make an outline on the paper and then transfer it to felt. Allow for distancer! (It is 10mm - 1cm high).   
I have used simple UHU to glue felt to inside of arcs which I have roughen with a file before. If printing separate arcs you might need to use sand paper or file to 'adjust' connectors (and maybe distancer's inside) a bit.

remixed_from.title: Mendel90 nozzle fan duct (90/360 open, for hexagon hotend)

title: Mendel90 x-carriage hotend fan duct (always on, for hexagon hotend)

description.text:
A small printed fan duct for the hexagon hotend (all metal hotend needing an always on fan for cooling the hotends heatsink). I am using a Mendel90, this fan duct is mounted on the left side of the x-carriage between the rods. No modification required for the x-carriage, you only need to drill a single 3mm bore. The fan duct ist attached using an M3 screw from the top of the x-carriage (see last picture). inside the duct, there is a nut trap for an M3 nut. The fan duct needs to be printed standing on the fan mounting bracket (tilt the stl in your host software before slicing/printing). The fixed support structure (see stl rendering) on the fan intake side needs to be removed after printing. I am using this fan duct with a 40mm 12V fan, in fact with the fan that was part of the hexagon kit. The duct is long enough to reach quite close to the hotend. For my setup, this works really well, there ist no heat intake from the hotend into the x-carriage or the extruder - and my extruder is printed in PLA! This fan duct is used in conjunction with my
Mendel90 nozzle fan duct (90/360 open, for hexagon hotend)
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335504)
and is designed to fit smoothly on top of the nozzle fan duct. The cutout at the top of the fan duct (towards the hotend) is for the extruder mounting to still be accessible when the duct is mounted (see 3rd picture).

This thing needs to be printed tilted, ie standing on the fan mount bracket. Inside the fan inlet there is a deliberately added thin support frame, which needs to be removed after printing. The cantilever for the connection to the x-carriage is angled from below (ie in print/z-direction, after tilting), so should print ok, if you have some cooling while printing. Otherwise, just print it slowly. Even if if doesn't come out as smooth as expected, it will be hidden underneath the x-carriage when mounted.  
I usually print with 2 perimeters and 25% infill in PLA.  
After printing, carefully remove the support structure in the fan intake.  
Mount a 40mm 12V fan, the holes are for M3 screws. For the hexagon hotend this fan needs to be always operating for cooling the insulator/heatsink piece.  
You need to drill a single 3mm hole into you x-carriage. For drilling a straight hole, I had to remove the extruder body. On the fan duct, measure the distance from the end of the fan intake frame to the attachment bore on top of the duct. Measure the same distance on top of your x-carriage from the left edge. At this distance drill a 3mm hole that is in the middle between the x-carriage rods.  
In the fan duct, insert a M3 nut from inside the duct. This might work best if you take a longer (20mm) M3 screw, put it into the duct, loosely attache the screw and then tighten the screw until the nut is pullled into the nut trap. Then, release the longer screw and attach the fan duct to the x-carriage using a short screw and a washer.  
Make sure, the fan is always on when operating the printer. The hexagon (all-metal) hotend needs a constant air movement across the heatsink fins.  
For removing/attaching or servicing the fan duct, no removal of the extruder is required. Just use a long screw driver, you should be able to loosen/set the M3 screw even when the extruder is mounted.

author: onebeartoe

description.text:
ArduBot is home made robot fully printed on the reprap 3D printer. It is based on arduino nano board, servos and ultrasonic sensor. It is easy to print, assemble, small, fun and great intro into electronics and robotics.
ArduBot is fully controlled by IR remote control and it has 3 modes:
  • Manual control by IR remote ( forward, backward, right and left)
  • Autonomous mode ( ArduBot navigates to avoiding obstacles and choosing the best way.)
  • Monitor mode ( ArduBot is monitorng objects in front of the ultrasonic sensor. )
    • Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4a9aTn8atQU If you want to build ArduBot, you can downolad souce code, schematic and also 3D designs at: https://github.com/davidhrbaty/ArduBot

The robot assembling is easy. Follow these instructions:
1) Print all these parts:
1x Front mount part
1x Rear mount part
1x Speaker cube part
1x Speaker grille part
1x Battery holder part
1X Battery pack part
1x hc-sr04 front part
1x hc-sr04 back part
1x small wheel holder part
1x small wheel holder top part
1x small wheel part
2x main wheel part 2) Parts you need to buy:
1x Ultrasonic sensor HC-SR04
2x Servo motor Futaba S3003
1x Micro servo motor SG90
1x Arduino Nano rev. 3
1x IR receiver TSOP382 or another
1x PC Speaker
4x AAA battery 3) Hack Futaba servos so they can turn 360 degrees, instructions are for exampe on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SK8mhnEzcvY
4) Assembly all parts together
5) Connect everything with schematic on https://github.com/davidhrbaty/ArduBot
6) Modify program to your IR remote controll
7) Upload program to Arduino which you can download from https://github.com/davidhrbaty/ArduBot
8) Insert batteries into battery pack
9) Ready to go :-)

After printing, sand the rim well. If you printed in PLA, sand some more, and then keep sanding! For PLA, I usually also apply a torch (very carefully!) to further smooth the rim surface that your face comes into contact with.

description.text: Customisable low profile Terminal Cover for the Power Supply commonly used with the Bukobot and other 3d printers. Includes power socket, flexible power out connection support, switch and power LED without compromising safety or style.

I was looking for a terminal cover and found a few on Thingiverse. Unfortunately none had what I needed or had serious weaknesses. For example, they were either too large, didn't protect the terminals completely, didn't provide a power socket or lacked an externally visible power LED. This cover supports all features and allows you to adjust all settings to support your own switch dimensions etc. DISCLAIMER:
Please ensure you are careful with all wiring as any power supply modifications involve dangerous voltages. Do not perform these modifications unless you know what you are doing. Proceed at your own risk. I do not accept any liability. TO CREATE:
Simply change the cutout parameters in OpenSCAD to suit. Note: do not change length, height, depth and thickness parameters for the base unless you want to change the core dimensions. TO INSTALL:
I sourced the power connector from an old printer and was able to bend the rear connectors so they fitted snug in the case (make sure you insulate all connections!). I extended the LED by carefully soldering some connection wires from the base of the existing LED. I used a rubber grommet to route the 12v output connection. This also allows additional cables to be routed later if needed. If you create a small hole in the grommet and then pull through the wires, it will be nicely sealed and will grab sufficiently to prevent the cables being pulled off the terminal block. If you don't have a grommet, a cable tie will suffice to prevent the cable being pulled through. I added screw holes to the slot retainers for extra safety to ensure the cover cannot be easily dislodged. Enjoy!

description.text: Simple design to stabilize the aluminium i3 frame that's not too fussy about the angle and easy to retrofit (just replace the rear threaded bars with longer ones)

I've found I've been seeing quite a lot of wobble on my aluminium plate i3 when printing. This is partly down to me printing on a wobbly table and partly due to mounting the spool on the top. So to rectify this I've made these parts which allowed me to retrofit stabilizers to the plate making everything so much sturdier.  
I didn't know the exact angle of the plate so I've created the parts to be flexible enough to fit anywhere from 15 degrees to 35 degrees - the median point being the rough measurement of 25 degrees which I'd measured in my setup (having just checked the actual angle turned out to be 20 degrees.  
There are many similar designs but none that I saw had the flexibility I wanted from my design.  
Enjoy.

• 2 x 400mm (ish) M10 threaded rod
  • 8 x M10 nuts
  • 8 x M10 washers
  • 2 x 370mm (ish) M8 threaded rod
  • 8 x M8 nuts
  • 8 x M8 washers
  • 4 x M4x16mm bolts

comments.text: Best Frame stabilzer in my opinion.

title: 3D Printable Folding Iron Sights V1.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this so it would only require a rubber band to function, since a rubber band is a more common item than an actual spring.
Both the Front and the Rear sight is adjustable. It is inspired by Magpuls new iron sights, and the locking mechanism was inspired by my Airsoft PTS sight. ---UPDATES---

  • V1.1
    Thanks to Viktor Jensen, aka "No_Aim". For the idea about adding a hole for a spring in the sights!

  • V1.0
    Found some really bad design choices on the rubber band holder. They where making printing the folding parts unnecessary difficult to print. (Removing the old files since there is nothing better about them)

  • V0.9.6
    Rotating and re-scaling stl files, and removing non-threaded parts.

  • V0.9.5
    Uploaded a stronger rear sight.

  • V0.9: I added physical treads to the parts that needed it. But I will be keeping the old files on as well, for those who want to add treads by hand.
    I also made some changes to the Lock file. I made the text extrude inwards, since it would need some unnecessary rafts.
    I have also added a simple bolt and nut for mounting the sight to the weapon.
    Updated the base so it would be a slightly stronger, and had the hole for the nut raised a little.
    • If someone prints a set, I would love to see some images :-) I can't wait to get my own printer home!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Please refer to my two sheets in the gallery for the assembly of the sights. Where the rubber band is fitted in, I will show that as soon as possible.  
Keep in mind that most 3D fillament shrink a little during cooling, so to make the pins and hole fit, please either drill the holes after printing or downscale the pins a little in the slicer software.

comments.text:
You can generate supports through the slicer program you have but you'll have to refer to your program on how to do that. Adding supports manually requires you to do it through the program you used to make the stls. I make a support and leave a 0.2mm gap between the support and the model so that it provides support and at the same time it's easy to break off. It's kinda hard to explain but see my rail I made that used built in breakaway-support http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:670429/#instructions.
Also, I would recommend actually flipping the Front and Rear so that it's standing vertically with the wider end up. This will reduce the amount of support needed to be printed for that.

comments.text:
XYZ DV 1.0 is far from the worst 3D Printer :). You got an surprisingly good 3DP for that amount of money. Besides that, if any probs appear on the XYZ software, check your files with Meshmixer's inspector. If any errors are in the file, you'll know and be able to fix it. But its highly doubtful since the files are repaired at netfabbs online repairservice.
A possibility however is that XYZ's software does not agree with my designed wall thickness...
In that case, offsetting with meshmixer/meshlab(google it) could work, you'll just have to take a drill to the backplate's holes afterwards.

comments.text:
No. if u place the cloud face down the pegs heads on top will need suport as well.
Printing upwards is the only way the model can be printed without support and still CLICK.
after the first peg layers fail, the filament starts attaching @ the pegs axles.
if u print it face down, that technique doesn't fly.

author: LucidOne

description.text:
This is a wider replacement for the standard Y Rod Mount for 8mm smooth rods found in the MendelMax 1.5. The default Y Rod Mount is set to 100mm rod center to rod center - this .stl has that distance lengthened to 136mm for a much wider and more stable base for your MendelMax Y carriage. The OpenSCAD script is dependent upon the original Y Rod Mount from kludgineer's "MendelMax 1.5". It is parametric, so simply set the rod distance you desire, and you'll get an .stl that works for your specifics. (Just make sure it still fits on your print bed). Two of these are needed per MendelMax 1.5 printer. Also check out the cleaner to print clasps that go with the parametric Y mount:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:61633

If the 136mm (rod center to rod center) spacing works for you, simply download, print, and enjoy. If the original 100mm spacing works for you, then go with kludgineer's original part. If you need a different spacing, follow these steps:
  • Download kludgineer's original "Y_Rod_Mount_2_off.stl" object.
  • Download the "ParametricYRodMount.scad" script that is part of this thing.
  • Make sure both files are in the same directory.
  • Open the ParametricYRodMount.scad file using OpenSCAD (tested in OpenSCAD version 2013.01 and OpenSCAD 2011.12).
  • Find the comment "// STEP 1: Set this parameter to the measured or desired distance between your y smooth rods".
  • Edit the value of the "actual_y_smooth_rod_distance" variable on the following line. The value is specified in mm.
  • If you want to see where the rods would go, find the comment "// STEP 2: ..." and uncomment the two cylinders that visually show you where the rods would be in this model.
  • As directed in "// STEP 3: ...", do a "Design" -> "Compile and Render (CGAL)", or simply hit F6.
  • Once the object has been compiled and rendered, you can save off an .stl using "Design" -> "Export as STL..."
  • Enjoy!

This is bar-end for Bicycle. I was designed it to fit any handle bar of bicycle (bar tube diameter = 22.2 mm.).  
For make one pair of this you need to print "barend 01-2.STL" for 4 copy (because I design it for half assembly) and "barend 02.STL" for 2 copy.

Print ABS with no support. I recomment to set shell perimeters = 5 and Fill density = 30%  
Use hot glue to assemble all piece together. I use M3 25 mm. screw as core reinforcement to hardened. After assembly please use Acetone Vapor Finishing to make it look nicer and more stronger. (because outer layer of ABS was fuse by Acetone).

Printed on an UP mini in UV colour changing filament from 3D Printing Systems (goes from white to purple in the sun). You will probably need support...
